Call this bhiká¹£u here.

How should one sleep?
One is not allowed to sleep like a hungry ghost, like an asura, or like a lustful person.

The Buddha was staying at ÅšrÄvastÄ«. At that time, the group of six monks closed the monastery door and sat together talking. When visiting monks came and knocked on the door, they did not hear it and then climbed over the wall to enter.
The old monks asked:
Venerables, where did you come in from?
They replied:
We came in by climbing over the wall.
The old monks said:
Why did you climb over the wall to enter?
The visiting monks said:
Why did you close the door and not respond when we called?
Thus they argued together.
They went and told the World-Honored One, and the Buddha said:
From now on, you should not close the door and talk, nor should you climb over the wall to enter.
From now on, visiting monks should do this, and old monks should do that.
What does it mean to do this?
When visiting monks are traveling, they should carry a door hook, a water strainer, and a needle case. If one companion has them, it is all without offense.
If there are none at all, the entire assembly is guilty.
If there are sick people on the road, they should carry each other's robes and bowls. They should not go far ahead, but should support each other and go together.
If someone is unable to walk, they should borrow a vehicle to carry them.
If there is wet dew on the road, the younger ones should go in front.
If they fear thieves, tigers, or wolves, the elders should be in the middle.
If they want to make thieves give rise to a compassionate mind, the elders should go in front.
If they pass by a caitya by the side of the road in a village, they should walk along the usual path and should not go down the road to the left or right.

When it is evening and they want to stay overnight, they should first send two young monks ahead to find a place to stay, to ask for out-of-season drinks and oil for the feet, and for food before and after.
Those who leave should put on their robes and fasten them, and inform that they are entering the village at an improper time. Having obtained [a place to stay], they should return and report:
'We have found a place to stay.
If there is pond water or well water, they should wash and put on their robes, and then enter one by one.
If they wish to drink honey water, they should drink it outside to avoid giving rise to suspicion that they are eating at the wrong time.
They should not carry anything into the monastery, but divide up the belongings and enter together.
If they are given a place to stay, there is no offense for later people to enter without announcing.
They should not take a different route, but if there is a covered path, there is no offense.
If there is a monastery in the village, they should go there. If it is a forest dwelling place, they should wash at the nearby pond or well and enter.
They should not carry anything, but divide up the belongings and take off their shoes and carry their staffs. If there is a caitya, they should circumambulate it clockwise.
They should not enter speaking loudly or making loud noises.
When they see senior monks, they should not say:ğŸ”½Hey!
Hey!
Are you still here?
You were born here and will die here, not leaving this wilderness to be eaten by jackals.
The resident monks should not say:
'Oh no!
Oh no!
It's like a prisoner who has escaped from shackles, and cannot be seen for four or five years.'
The visiting monks should not say:
'How many years have you been ordained?
I should get this room.'
They should not ask:
'Who is preparing the morning and evening meals tomorrow? Are there good foods?'
The resident monks should not close the door and talk.
If they want to do plastering work or other tasks after the monastery, they should have the gardener, novice monk, rector, gatekeeper, or door closer do it.
The visiting monks should not climb over the wall to enter, but should open the door with the door hook.
If they are called to open the door and enter, the resident monks should ask:
'How many years have you been ordained?'
They should reply:
'I have so many years of ordination.'
The resident monks say:
'If you stay for so many years, you can get such a bed and bedding.'
You should ask about the places for defecating and urinating in advance, and not ask at the last minute.
Next, you should ask about the Sangha's restrictions. The old monks should say:
'The Sangha has restrictions. Do not go to such-and-such a household where the bowl has been overturned. The dog in such-and-such a household is vicious. Such-and-such a household has no faith.'
The visiting monks should get up early and not leave to beg for food right away. They should ask:
'Is there a pre-meal or post-meal meal at this residence?'
The old monks should say:
'Elders, do not beg for food. Begging for food is tiring and may not be to your liking. There is a pre-meal and post-meal meal here.'
If the companions have already left, you should not say:
'Elder!
You can catch up because the merchants have already left.'
You should say:
'Elder!
Please rest for a while. There will be companions soon.'
If there is an urgent matter and one must leave, one should be provided with provisions and entrusted to a fellow traveler.
The guest monks and the resident monks should follow these rules.
If one does not follow them, one commits an offense of wrong conduct.
The Buddha was staying at ÅšrÄvastÄ«. At that time, the group of six monks washed their feet and played in the water while chatting.
The monks went to inform the World-Honored One of this cause and condition.
The Buddha said:
From today onwards, when washing the feet, one should follow ÅšÄriputra's method.

The Buddha was staying at Kalandaka Bamboo Grove in RÄjagá¹›ha. At that time, ÅšÄriputra put on his outer robe, took his bowl, entered the city in order, and went for alms. His deportment was dignified, his coming and going were well-considered, and he bent and looked up while wearing his robe and carrying his bowl. The brÄhmans saw this and thought:
These Å›ramaá¹‡as, sons of ÅšÄkya, maintain dignified conduct in public, but when they reach a secluded place, they must have no rules. I will follow and observe them.
If I see them indulging themselves, I will slap their heads with my hand.
So he immediately followed behind.
Then ÅšÄriputra did not change his dignified conduct in the village or in the secluded forest.
When he reached his dwelling place, he placed his alms bowl in one place, shook out his saá¹ƒghÄá¹­Ä« robe, folded it, and placed it in its usual spot.

He spread out his sitting mat, took the foot-washing board and water jar, sat down nearby, and then took off his leather shoes, shook them, and put them on the ground. Next, he took a towel to wipe his shins, and then took the leather shoes again, put the soles together, held them, and wiped them with the towel.
Next, he soaked the towel with water, wiped the tip of one leather shoe and the straps and laces, and then wiped the base;
and he also did the same for the second one.
He then wiped the toes of the first shoe he was holding, and then wiped the heel;
and he also did the same for the second one.
Next, wring out the towel and dry it, then wash your hands.
After washing your hands, pour water with your right hand and wash your left thigh, then wash your right thigh, and then wash your feet.
The brahmin saw this and was filled with joy, saying:
The Venerable One is so pure and clean, even the remaining water can be drunk. The purity of the water in our brahmin rituals does not compare to this.
At that time, Shariputra took advantage of the brahmin's joyful mind and expounded the Dharma for him, enabling him to attain the pure Dharma-eye.
The bhiká¹£us said to the Buddha:
World-Honored One!
This is excellent!
The brahmin saw Shariputra's pure demeanor in washing his feet and was filled with joy, to the point of this.
The Buddha said:
This is not just joy for today, but also in the past world, it was already like this, as extensively explained in the Birth Stories.
At that time, the son of the elder was Shariputra;
The thief at that time is now the brÄhmaá¹‡a.
At that time, the devas, having seen this, spoke a verse, saying:
Pure and good deportment, because of this one obtains good benefits,
Just like a pure reflection appears in the water, learning deportment is supreme.
Coming with an evil mind, having seen it one turns and rejoices,
Not learning good deportment, one will certainly be harmed by thieves.

If a bhiká¹£u returns to the village, he should take off the robe worn when entering the village, shake it out, fold it, and put it back in its usual place. He should put on the robe worn in the garden, spread out the sitting mat and foot-washing board, fill the water jar, and use the towel to wipe off the dust on his feet.

Next, he should take the leather sandals, place the soles together, hold the towel and wipe them, next moisten the towel and wipe one strap and nose, next wipe the base, and next wipe the second one in the same way.
Then take the first one again, first wiping between the toes, then wiping the heel, and then wiping the second one in the same way.
Next, wash the towel, wring it out, and dry it, not allowing dust or insects to get to it, and then wash your hands.

If the water vessel is on the right side, you should first wash the left leg, then wash the right leg, and then wash your feet. You should not use the hand that holds the water to rub your feet. You should pour water with one hand and massage with the other.
If there are two people, one pours water and the other washes. You should not waste too much water. You should use it sparingly.
You should not cover your head or cover your right shoulder. You should sit with your right shoulder bared.
You should not sit in meditation, sleep, contemplate impurity, or recite sutras while washing your feet. When you are finished, you should move aside and not obstruct other people.
If you are the last to wash, you may recite sutras without offense.
If the water is exhausted, you should not remain silent. You should tell the person in charge of water to add more.
If one is unable to do so, one should at least benefit oneself by using a single water dipper to make it usable for one person.
The method of washing feet should be like this.
If it is not like this, it is a transgression of the rules of deportment.

The Buddha was staying at ÅšrÄvastÄ«. At that time, the group of six monks washed their feet, then put on their leather shoes with wet feet. The dye on the leather shoes came off and stained the monks' bedding.

Summon the group of six monks.
After they arrived, the Buddha asked the monks:
Is it true that you did this?
They replied:
It is true, World-Honored One!
The Buddha said:

If there are many people waiting, you should wipe off the water with your hand and wipe it with a towel, and then put on the leather shoes.
One should not step on the pure ground made by the Sangha with wet feet. One should wait until it is dry before entering.
If it is a place for one person to wash, one should not wipe it, but should wait until it is dry and then put on leather shoes.

One should protect it from dust and dirt. If one urgently wants to sit in meditation, recite scriptures, or practice walking meditation, one should wipe the dust and dirt off with one's hands or a towel before leaving.
The method of washing feet should be like this.
If one does not do it like this, one is transgressing the rules of deportment.

The Buddha was staying in ÅšrÄvastÄ«. At that time, the Sangha's clean water and maá¹‡á¸ala were used by the bhiká¹£us to wash their feet, wash their hands and faces, and wash their bowls. Like the water of SÅ«na in PÄá¹­aliputra, the hot spring water in RÄjagá¹›ha, the water of the Buddha's travel pond in VÄrÄá¹‡asÄ«, the Ganges water in CampÄ, the molasses water in ÅšrÄvastÄ«, the cascading water in SÄketa, the molasses water in Saá¹ƒkÄsya, and the RÄmaá¹‡aka water in MathurÄ. Such waters are not allowed to be used for washing feet, hands, face, or bowls.
If one is sick and needs water, one should be given a full bowl.

The person receiving water should protect the left hand to keep it clean when receiving water. If the hand is dirty, it should be rinsed.

If drinking out of season, the person distributing the drink should first wash their hands and vessel before distributing. The person receiving the drink should also wash their hands before receiving it.
If not washed, it should be received using a leaf or clean cloth to support the bottom of the vessel as above, up to the mouth, and discarded.
If drinking in the bathhouse, one should use a leaf to support the bottom of the vessel and drink from it, the rest as explained above.

If the seats are separated, one person should carry the vessel and one person should carry the water, the rest as explained above.
This is called good water. One should not use it to wash feet, hands, face, or rinse the bowl, nor should one use it for other purposes and discard it.
If there is a need for making robes and bowls, one may borrow it temporarily and repay it.
If the water is used at will, one may take it as one wishes without offense.

If one sits in the water up to the navel, it is also allowed.

The Buddha was staying at ÅšrÄvastÄ«. One day every five days, the World-Honored One would go to the monks' quarters to inspect. He saw that the clean kitchen utensils were scattered all over the place. The Buddha knew but deliberately asked:

The Buddha said:
From today onwards, the utensils should not be allowed to be scattered like this.ğŸ”½If it is the monastery superintendent or the treasurer, they should have the gardener or novice monk clean up.

If the monastery superintendent or the treasurer do not use their own judgment, they should have the lay workers clean up. If the earthenware cauldrons, pots, and other utensils, it is the same.
Cover the ground with bricks and tiles to suppress them. Wooden buckets and wooden ladles should also be washed and lifted up.

If there are mats and bedding, they should be dried in the sun and hung up. Bamboo baskets, winnowing baskets, and rice sieves should also be hung up to prevent insects from eating them. Rice boxes and rice scoops should be washed and hung up. Cloth bags and water strainers should also be hung up to prevent insects from eating them.
Pestles and mortars for pounding medicine should not be used and then left on the ground. They should be washed and covered and placed in their usual place.
In the kitchen and clean rooms, one should not neglect to repair holes and leaks. If covered with grass, it should be repaired with grass, up to mud-covered ones that should be repaired with mud.
Holes and cracks should be filled, and it should be swept frequently.

When adding firewood to the inner fire, it should be arranged in one place. Dyeing vessels and dye buckets should not be left unused. They should be washed and cleaned and placed in their usual place.
Wooden buckets for washing clothes should also be washed and placed in their usual place after use.

Axes, saws, shovels, picks, and ladders are the property of the Saá¹…gha of the four directions. After use, they should be put away in the usual place, so that those who need them later can easily find and use them, without being exhausted.
If they are needed, they should be given out. If two people request them at the same time, they should be given to the senior monk first.
If the senior monk has used them for a long time and the junior monk needs to use them, they should be given to the junior monk first.
If both have used them for a short time, they should be given to the senior monk first.
The rules for using utensils should be like this.
If it is not like this, it is a violation of the rules of deportment.

The Buddha was staying at ÅšrÄvastÄ«. At that time, village monks and forest monks shared a donation. The forest monks always came on time, but the village monks suddenly beat the gavel early and ate.

What does it mean to act like this?

If the monks in the forest and the village monks are invited to the same offering, the village monks should not get up early, beat the gandi, and eat before or after the meal or accept invitations, they should wait for the monks in the forest.
The monks in the forest should not say:
'I will go slowly, they will wait for me.'
They should go first.

'Have the forest monks come yet?'

If an upÄsaka invites the Sangha, the village monks should tell the forest monks:

Having heard this, the forest monks should come early. If they come and the food is not yet ready, they should not stay and wait. They should pay homage to the stÅ«pa, recite the sÅ«tras, and inquire about the Dharma.

They should praise, saying:

If not, it is a violation of the rules of deportment.

Then cover the lamps with your hand and chant:ğŸ”½'The lamps are about to be extinguished!

Do not blow them out with your mouth, fan them out with your hand or fan, or fan them out with your robe. Instead, twist the wick and let it burn out.
In the latter part of the night, get up again and first light the latrine, then the walking path, then the entrance to the walkway, and finally the lamps in the meditation hall.
When lighting the lamps in the meditation hall, do not enter abruptly, but announce:
'Venerable ones!ğŸ”½The lamp is about to enter!
The lamp is about to enter!'

When dawn is about to end, first extinguish the lamps at the end of the corridors, then extinguish the lamps in the walking area, then extinguish the lamps in the latrine, then extinguish the lamps in the meditation hall.
The method of lighting lamps should be like this.
If it is not like this, it is an offense for improper conduct.
The Buddha was staying at ÅšrÄvastÄ«. At that time, the bhiká¹£us were sitting in meditation in the meditation hall, dozing with their heads down.
The bhiká¹£us went to inform the World-Honored One of this cause and condition.

When the group of six bhiká¹£us were using the meditation staff, they hit the sides of the bhiká¹£us, and they immediately cried out in surprise:

Elder!
The bhiká¹£us went to inform the World-Honored One of this cause and condition. The Buddha said:

The method for making a meditation staff is to use bamboo or rattan, eight cubits long, with the two ends wrapped in cloth. The lower-ranking monk should carry it.
When carrying it, one should not cover the head, cover the right shoulder, or wear leather shoes. One should bare the right shoulder.

If there are those who are sleeping, one should not suddenly and urgently call them to wake up, nor should one rub their sides. One should stand beside them and tap in front of them three times with the staff.
If they still do not wake up, if they are on the left side, one should tap the right knee, if they are on the right side, one should tap the left knee.
